chapters.summary: Stick to the plan. Anticipate. Don't improvise. Empathy is weakness. Weakness is vulnerability. This is what it takes if you want to succeed.
chapters.headline: Stick to the plan. Don't improvise. Anticipate. This is what it takes if you want to succeed

chapters.summary: In the mid 20th century, Reno, Nevada was internationally known as the Divorce capital of the World. When early settlers colonized the US, they brought a range of divorce customs from Protestant Europe with them. For much of modern history, divorce has been very hard to do.
chapters.gist: The History of Divorce in Reno, Nevada
chapters.headline: Rod Phillips explores the history of divorce in Reno, Nevada

chapters.summary: Reno was selected as a stop on the Central Pacific Railroad in the mid 18 hundreds. A shorter residency period and more liberal grounds for divorce meant that it could technically be easier to get a divorce in Nevada. With Nevada's gold and silver mining depleted, politicians and businessmen in Reno were looking to take advantage of divorce tourism.
chapters.gist: Nevada's reputation as a divorce colony
chapters.headline: Reno became known as a divorce colony because of its short residency requirements

chapters.summary: About 500 black women came to Reno to divorce each year. These women needed to rely on Reno's local black community for support. Reno's casino industry was both entertainment for the divorce seekers as well as a place for employment.
chapters.gist: Black Women Visited Reno to Get a Divorce
chapters.headline: 500 black women came to Reno to divorce each year, according to 1950 article

chapters.summary: Reno held the title of Divorce Capital of the World for a little over six decades. The American public was fed a steady stream of Reno divorce drama from Hollywood films. Reno's divorce era began petering out in the late 1960s as divorce law became more liberalized.
chapters.gist: The Divorce Capital of the World: Reno
chapters.headline: Reno held the title of Divorce Capital of the World for decades

chapters.summary: There are love locks on the Virginia Street Bridge, the bridge where women cast off their wedding rings for decades. This was a bridge of liberation. Maybe these aren't locks dedicated to self love. At the very least, these couples already know of a fun place to get divorced.
chapters.gist: The Secret to Getting Divorced in Reno
chapters.headline: There are love locks on Reno's Virginia Street Bridge

chapters.headline: With annuity and life insurance solutions from Lincoln Financial, you're helping yourself out

chapters.summary: Ellie Gordon Marshall: I actually brought my girlfriend on my Reno divorce trip. It turned out that place was the Northern Nevada LGBTQ Center. Marshall: The film was based on a novel by Jane Rule. It was the first mainstream lesbian film to have a happy ending.
chapters.gist: Desert of the Heart: A Lesbian Divorce Story
chapters.headline: Ellie Gordon Marshall brought her girlfriend to Reno for a divorce story

chapters.summary: Jane Rule's long term partner Helen went to Reno for a divorce in 1958. While they were in Reno, Jane actually got a job at a casino. Their ashes are at the Galliano Island Cemetery. Are you going to go and pay your respects?
chapters.headline: Roman: I read Desert of the heart about a year ago

chapters.summary: 99% Invisible was produced this Week by Ellie Gordon Marshall, edited by Vivian Ley. We are part of the Stitcher and SiriusXM podcast family. You can find us on most social media platforms, but I can recommend one place that does feel good are our website 99 pi. org.
chapters.headline: Roman Mars thanks Jane for introducing us to Reno
